key_points: Human remains found inside a massive alligator in Louisiana were confirmed to be those of Timothy Satterlee, missing since August 30 after an alligator attack.
Satterlee's disappearance followed Hurricane Ida, marking what may be Louisiana's first fatal alligator attack in modern times.
The 71-year-old victim's wife witnessed the attack, seeing the alligator rip off one of Satterlee's arms.
Despite seeking help, when the wife returned, both Satterlee and the alligator were gone.
Two weeks later, the alligator, measuring 12 feet long and weighing 504 pounds, was captured and killed by deputies near Satterlee's home. Human remains were found inside.
St. Tammany Parish Coroner Dr. Charles Preston indicated he would likely rule Satterlee's death as an accident.
Louisiana is home to over 2 million wild alligators, yet fatal attacks on humans are extremely rare.
Historically, there's at least one other suspected fatal alligator attack in Louisiana, dating back to 1774.
On average, alligators are responsible for one human death annually in the U.S., per the University of Florida.
Hurricane Ida was a catastrophic storm that caused widespread devastation in Louisiana and the Northeast, resulting in numerous deaths, mainly from flooding.
spokespersons: Dr. Charles Preston (St. Tammany Parish Coroner)
